block.p: Budget Office Predicts Further Decline in Deficit The nonpartisan Congressional Budget Office predicted that the federal budget deficit would shrink again this year and could actually swing into a surplus in 2012 -- but only if President Bush's tax cuts expire in 2010.

The agency predicted that the deficit for 2007 would decline to about $200 billion. It would be the third big annual decline in a row. The decline comes on the heels of unexpectedly large increases in tax revenue and slower-than-expected increases in spending on Medicare.
PAGE A21

Kerry Rules Out an '08 Race Senator John Kerry, the Massachusetts Democrat who narrowly lost the presidency to President Bush in 2004, announced that he would not proceed with a second bid for the White House. ''We came close, certainly close enough to be tempted to try again,'' Mr. Kerry said at the end speech attacking Mr. Bush's Iraq policy on the Senate floor.

N.F.L. Enhances Drug Policy The N.F.L. and its players union said that they have agreed to strengthen the league's testing program for performance-enhancing drugs, including increasing the number of tests and adding financial penalties.

Life's Hard-Won Pleasures Jim Harrison, author of rugged, outdoorsy books like ''True North'' and ''Legends of the Fall,'' has spent a vigorous life, and he has been known to hold his own at the table with trenchermen like Orson Welles and John Huston. Now, at 69, health problems have slowed him down, but he still identifies food with literature and a love of life.
